Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Synthetic methodology for the preparation of polycyclic nitrogen or oxygen containing heterocycles
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this CAREER Award, the Organic and Macromolecular Chemistry Program is supporting the research of Professor Matthias Brewer of the Chemistry Department at the University of Vermont. This project will develop new methods for the synthesis of nitrogen or oxygen containing organic compounds from simple starting materials. These methods, based on the reaction of hydrazones with sulfonium ions, will provide new ways to access reactive intermediates under mild and environmentally benign conditions. These reactive intermediates will be studied for their ability to participate in unprecedented sigmatropic rearrangements, electrophilic aromatic substitutions, and cycloadditions, and will also be evaluated for reactivity in a variety of synthetic transformations. This research will provide biomedical researchers with new tools to prepare biologically active compounds that are often difficult to synthesize by current methods.

Professor Brewer will also initiate educational projects focused on the development of environmentally beneficial green chemical methods and their integration into the undergraduate curriculum. Green chemistry experiments will be developed in senior-level organic laboratories for use in the lower-level undergraduate laboratories. The PI will also oversee a partnership between undergraduate students and a local aquarium/science center to develop outreach educational materials designed to introduce a general audience to environmentally benign green chemistry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching objective of this research was to establish new synthetic organic methodology to facilitate the synthesis of heterocyclic molecules. Nitrogen heterocycles are particularly important because they are ubiquitous in biologically active compounds. The work performed under this grant was primarily based on studying the formation and subsequent reactivity of 1-aza-2-azoniaallene cations in intramolecular reactions. During this work new ways to prepare these intermediates were established, and it was discovered that these intermediates can react intramolecularly by several different pathways to provide four different kinds of nitrogen heterocycles and one kind of carbocycle. Several of these reactions are totally unprecedented and provide interesting and useful structurally-complex products from simple starting materials. In several cases, the products that are formed are themselves reactive species that will undoubtedly be useful synthetic intermediates. Overall, this work provides biomedical researchers new tools to prepare structurally complex molecules from trivial starting materials for medicinal evaluation.

In addition, this grant funded two undergraduate students to help develop outreach materials related to green chemistry in partnership with a local science center. Ultimately, a visually appealing outreach display that interpreted green chemistry concepts to a general public audience using biodegradable polymers as a case in point was developed. The display was located on the science center’s main floor for five months. The students also developed and delivered daily a hands-on “Green Chemistry Encounter” and a 30-minute “Green Chemistry Demonstration” that included a chemical experiment. In addition, the PI developed a 30-minute presentation which was delivered to the science center’s public audience on two occasions as part of their “Meet the Scientist” program. The PI also implemented a multi-year plan to incorporate green chemistry concepts and laboratories into UVM’s undergraduate organic curriculum and partnered with UVM’s Environmental Safety staff to teach students about waste management issues.

The research described above was carried out by six graduate students and five undergraduate students who each received training in synthetic organic chemistry laboratory techniques, reaction design, methods development, and spectroscopic techniques for molecular structure determination. Four graduate students completed their Ph.D. dissertations and are now either conducting postdoctoral studies at a major research University, hold a position in industry, or teach at a University. Of the undergraduates, one has entered medical school, two have entered chemistry graduate programs, and one has enrolled in a teacher certification program to become a high school science teacher. In addition, the two undergraduate students who worked with the PI to develop outreach materials for the local science center have since enrolled in teacher certification programs to become high school science teachers.
